title: Brazil’s Central Bank Raises Rates for Third Time in a Row
sub_head: Selic benchmark up to 4.25%; more increases are likely, bank indicates, citing inflation
body:
Brazil’s central bank, the first among major economies to raise interest rates since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, increased them again on Wednesday, as rising inflation and a slow pace of vaccinations threaten economic recovery.
The move by 0.75 percentage point, as expected, was the third in a row, lifting the Selic benchmark lending rate to 4.25% from a historic low of 2% set last year to shore up the economy during the pandemic.
Brazil’s monetary authority said more rate increases are likely. Many economists say such measures are necessary to ensure inflation doesn’t get out of hand, as it often has in the past.
“The bank had to react and tighten monetary policy to avoid losing control over inflation,” said Pedro Paulo Silveira, an economist at brokerage firm Nova Futura Investimentos.
Mr. Silveira noted the bank changed its communication to indicate the intention to move monetary policy to “normal” levels, from the softer stance adopted during the pandemic.
